teaching.topicContent: Identify and explore equivalent fractions with denominators 2, 4, 8, and 10.Understand how fractions can represent the same value with different denominators.
Construct and cut out simple fractions using regular shapes.Use paper folding and cutting to visually represent fractions.
Record fractions using diagrams and fraction charts.Practice representing fractions visually to reinforce understanding.
Compare and order fractions with appropriate denominators.Learn to position fractions on the number line.
Use concrete materials to calculate fractions of a set.Apply practical understanding of fractions through manipulatives.
Develop an understanding of the relationship between fractions and division. Connect division concepts to fractional values (e.g., 1/3 of 12 = 4).
Calculate a unit fraction of a number. Apply unit fractions to calculate parts of quantities.
Explore, compare, and record equivalence of fractions with denominators 2–12.Use concrete materials, folding, and charts to demonstrate equivalency.

teaching.topicTitle: Expressing Improper Fractions and Mixed Numbers
teaching.topicContent: Convert improper fractions to mixed numbers. Position them on the number line and establish equivalence.
Compare and establish equivalence using concrete materials. Deepen understanding of equivalent fractions through hands-on exploration.
Use equivalent fractions to simplify addition and subtraction. Apply equivalent fractions to streamline calculations.
Calculate a number gien a multiple fraction of the number.Solve problems like 'What is 3/4 of 12?' and find the number.
Express one number as a fraction of another. Learn to relate ratios to fractional representations.

teaching.topicTitle: Ordering Equivalence on the Number Line
teaching.topicContent: Order equivalent fractions on the number line. Use fraction charts to visually represent order.

teaching.topicTitle: Applying Equivalence to Improper Fractions and Mixed Numbers
teaching.topicContent: Apply equivalency concepts to improper fractions and mixed numbers. Use diagrams, numerals, and the number line to explore and record.
Add and subtract simple fractions and mixed numbers.Utilize equivalent fractions to simplify calculations.
Calculate a fraction of a number.Solve problems like 'What is 2/5 of 45?'.
Use fraction operations to solve real-life problems.Apply fractional knowledge to practical scenarios.
Compare and order fractions with various denominators. Deepen understanding of comparing fractions using diverse denominators.
Relate fractions to ratios. Express ratios as fractions, e.g., 3:6 = 1/2.

test.description: Put your Fractions knowledge to the test.

questions.content: Which of the following fractions is equivalent to 3/5?
If you cut a rectangular pizza into 8 equal slices and eat 4 slices, what fraction of the pizza remains?
Arrange the following fractions in ascending order: 3/4, 5/8, 1/2, 2/3.
If you have 2/5 of a pie and each pie is divided into 10 equal parts, how many parts of the whole pie do you have?
What is the relationship between fractions and division?
answers: Fractions are always smaller than division results.
Fractions have no relationship with division.
Fractions represent parts of a whole, and division helps find those parts.
Division is the same as multiplication when working with fractions.

questions.content: Calculate 1/4 of 32.
Which of the following fractions are equivalent to 7/10?
Convert 5/2 to a mixed number.
If you cut a strip of paper into 6 equal parts and color 4 parts, what fraction of the strip is colored?
Calculate 3/8 of 48.
If a recipe calls for 1/3 cup of sugar and you want to make three times the amount, how much sugar do you need?
What is the relationship between fractions and ratios?
answers: Fractions and ratios are the same concepts.
Fractions and ratios have no relationship.
Fractions are a way to express ratios in fraction form.
Ratios are fractions expressed as whole numbers.

Express the ratio 4:10 as a fraction in simplest form.

Simplify the fraction 12/18 to its simplest form.
